intro: Loranthus balansanus, commonly known as the Balansan mistletoe, is a hemiparasitic plant that attaches to the branches of its host trees, primarily in the family Fabaceae. It lacks chlorophyll and relies on its host for water and nutrients, while producing its own sugars through photosynthesis using the light it captures. The plant forms a dense, leafy mass that can grow up to several meters in length, often creating a unique ecological niche. Its flowers are small and inconspicuous, typically green or yellowish, and it relies on insects for pollination. The berries it produces are red and fleshy, serving as a food source for birds and other animals.
